title: 1 it's both a perfect square and a perfect cube!
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Which of the following numbers is "},{"type":"text","text":"not","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" the product of a perfect square and a perfect cube?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"972 = 6^{2} \times 3^{3}, 900 = 30^{2} \times 1^{3}, 968 = 11^{2} \times 2^{3}, 961 = 31^{2} \times 1^{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"On the other hand, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"980 = 7^{2} \times 2^{2} \times 5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  cannot be written as the product of a perfect square and a perfect cube, as none of its divisors other than "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a perfect cube and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"980"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" itself is not a perfect square."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 1 LAKH POINTS PROBLEM!!!!
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A transparent sphere of radius "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"R"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and refractive index "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is at rest on a horizontal surface.A ray of light is incident parallel to the vertical diameter and at a distance "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" from it.Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be in range ("},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\alpha"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":","},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\beta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"].Find "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\alpha+\beta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".
Assume: The rays intersects the diameter at the point of emergence.See the figure.
The figure is as shown below:
"},{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/e9RAkR6ga9-brill13.jpg?width=1200"}}]}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":2}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                    
                                "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":2}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"So we get i=2ri=2ri=2r"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":2}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"sin(i)sin(r)\frac{sin(i)}{sin(r)}sin(r)sin(i)​=nnn"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":2}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"2cos(r)=n2cos(r)=n2cos(r)=n"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":2}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"sin(i)=sin(i)=sin(i)=dr\frac{d}{r}rd​"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":2}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"sin(2r)=sin(2r)=sin(2r)=dr\frac{d}{r}rd​"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":2}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now using simple algebraic manipulation we get that n22\frac{n^2}{2}2n2​=r+r2−d2r\frac{r+\sqrt{r^2-d^2}}{r}rr+r2−d2​​"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":2}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"0<d<=r0<d<=r0<d<=r"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":2}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence 2<n<=2\sqrt{2}<n<=22​<n<=2.So the answer is 2+2=3.414213562\sqrt{2}+2=3.4142135622​+2=3.414213562 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"NOTE:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"THIS IS INPHO 2007 QUESTION SO NO CLAIM OF ORIGINALITY IS MADE"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 111 Linear 222 Quadratics
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The polynomial "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3x^5+17x^4+3x^3+3x^2+17x+3"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" can be factorized as the product of one linear and two quadratics polynomials, whose leading coefficients are positive. What is the sum of all of the coefficients in the three factors?"}]}]}
